results.title: Aurore
results.brief_description:
Episode 2 of Series “Lagardere”.
Lagardere is in hiding in Spain with Aurore. He is still seeking to kill all those involved in that fateful night at Caylus 15 years ago. Each of his murders his signed with the famous ‘Nevers lunge’, a bloodied star on the forehead of the victim. Philippe has married Blanche in the hope of seizing her estate. He also keeps an army of informers whose mission it is to locate Lagardere and kidnap Aurore.

Credits: Producer, Robert Velin ; director, Jean-Pierre Decourt ; writers, Marcel Jullian, Jean-Pierre Decourt ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Jacques Loussier.
Cast: Jean Piat, Jacques Dufilho, Jean-Pierre Darras, Nadine Alari, Jacques Balutin, Claude Confortes, Marco Perrin.

results.title: Aurora
results.creator_credit: Peter Jones, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
An investigation of the mystery surrounding the Aurora Borealis. An Australian physicist, Dr Robert Eather, at Boston College, Massachusetts has developed a method of filming the aurora in color.

results.title: Aurelia Steiner
results.brief_description:
Variations on the theme of love messages: the author reads a love letter written by a Jewish girl living in Melbourne while travelling along the Seine.

results.title: Aunty Nancy and the easyplay
results.brief_description: Just released from a mental hospital for the 10th time, Aunty Nancy comes to stay with the relatives and our fearless narrator must vacate her room, again. Aunty Nancy can usually be tolerated, but only just. All that changes when she brings the easyplay - an electronic keyboard where she subjects them to a myriad of variations on “Chopsticks”.

results.title: Aunt Julia and the scriptwriter
results.creator_credit: Jon Amiel, Mark Tarlov, John Fiedler, Odyssey and Cinecom Entertainment
results.brief_description: Released in the United States as “Tune in tomorrow”, this is John Amiel’s screen version of Mario Vargas Llosa’s acclaimed novel “Aunt Julia and the scriptwriter”. Aunt Julia (Barbara Hershey), a double divorcee, returns to New Orleans at age 36 to find a wealthy third husband. Instead, she finds her 21-year-old nephew by marriage (Keanu Reeves), a local radio station newswriter, who falls in love with her. She succumbs to his advances, incurring her family’s anger. The plot is overlaid with the more complicated story of a dishevelled writer, Falk, who is new in town. Falk manipulates the nephew-aunt relationship in his radio soap opera which is laced with incest and anti-Albanian sentiment. This is a clever and witty romantic comedy that features an amazing supporting cast including John Laroquette, Elizabeth McGovern, Dennis Quaid and others.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jon Amiel, Mark Tarlov, John Fiedler, Odyssey and Cinecom Entertainment

results.title: Aujourd'hui en France: trois jours trois, photographes
results.brief_description: One of a series of films covering various aspects of the French lifestyle, history and culture. This film studies three French photographers - Jean-Loup Sieff, Robert Doisneau, Bruno Barbey - and their different styles.

results.title: Auguste and Louis Lumière
results.brief_description: In 1895 Auguste and Louis Lumière patented the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity, but its biggest achievement was projection.

constellations_primary.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_primary.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

results.description:
After learning about Thomas Edison’s Kinetograph in the early 1890s, Auguste and Louis Lumière set out to free motion pictures from Edison’s bulky contraption. In 1895 they succeeded, patenting the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity. But its biggest achievement was projection: while only one person could look through the Kinetograph’s peephole at a time, audiences could watch Cinématographe films together.

Alongside their invention, the Lumière brothers premiered 10 short films on daily life, known as actualités, including the famous Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896). The Cinématographe even inspired the new art form’s name: cinema.
description_for_label:
After learning about Thomas Edison’s Kinetograph in the early 1890s, Auguste and Louis Lumière set out to free motion pictures from Edison’s bulky contraption. In 1895 they succeeded, patenting the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity. But its biggest achievement was projection: while only one person could look through the Kinetograph’s peephole at a time, audiences could watch Cinématographe films together.

Alongside their invention, the Lumière brothers premiered 10 short films on daily life, known as actualités, including the famous Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896). The Cinématographe even inspired the new art form’s name: cinema.

results.title: Augusta
results.creator_credit: Anne Wheeler, Peter Jones, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is the portrait of Augusta Evans, an 88-year-old Indian woman (the daughter of a Shuswap chief), who lives alone in a log cabin without running water or electricity. She recalls past times, but lives very much in the present. Self-sufficient, dedicated to her people, she spreads warmth wherever she moves with her songs, her harmonica and her soft-voiced comments. Award: San Francisco.
